case_name: Wazirchand Mahajan & Anr. v. State of Himachal Pradesh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 601 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 601 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 27, 1961 of the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh, in first Civil Appeal Order No. 16 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 27, 1961 of Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh, in first Civil Appeal Order No. 16 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 27, 1961 of the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh, in first Civil Appeal Order No. 16 of 1958. L. Gosain and Harbans Singh, for the appellants.

facts.text: Agreement dated November 1, 1950 between Triloknath Mahajan (second appellant) and State of Himachal Pradesh for right to extract and collect medicinal herbs from Chamba District forests.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement dated November 1, 1950, with the State of Himachal Pradesh, Triloknath Mahajan-second appellant in this appeal-purchased the right to extract and companylect certain medicinal herbs from the forests of Chamba District. The period of the agreement was one year from September 1, 1950.

facts.text: Agreement period was one year from September 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The period of the agreement was one year from September 1, 1950. By cl. 22 of the agreement it was provided that all disputes between the parties arising under the agreement or under any clause thereunder or in any manner companynected with or arising out of the agreement or the operation thereof,

facts.text: Clause 22 of agreement provided for arbitration by sole arbitrator Deputy Commissioner, Mandi District, Himachal Pradesh, or appointed Assistant.

anchor.surface_text: By cl. 22 of the agreement it was provided that all disputes between the parties arising under the agreement or under any clause thereunder or in any manner companynected with or arising out of the agreement or the operation thereof, or the rights, duties or liabilities of either parties thereunder including the dispute or diffe- rence as to the companystruction of the agreement shall be referred to the sole arbitration of the Deputy Commissioner, Mandi District, Himachal Pradesh,

facts.text: Triloknath Mahajan transferred all rights, title and interest under the agreement to Wazirchand Mahajan (first appellant) with permission of State of Himachal Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: and if that officer be unable or unwilling to act, to such Assistant as the Deputy Commissioner shall appoint as the sole arbitrator. Triloknath Mahajan transferred all his rights, title and interest under the agreement to Wazirchand Mahajan-the first appellant-with the permission of the State of Himachal Pradesh.

facts.text: Disputes arose in October 1950 between appellants and State of Himachal Pradesh regarding right to collect herbs from certain areas and failure of State authorities to prevent trespassers.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose in October 1950 between the appellants and the State of Himachal Pradesh regarding the right to companylect herbs from certain areas and the failure of the State authorities to prevent trespassers from removing herbs, the right to which was granted to the second appellant.

facts.text: Appellants addressed letter on May 30, 1952 to Chief Conservator of Forests, Himachal Pradesh, requiring submission to arbitration of Deputy Commissioner, Mandi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants addressed a letter on May 30, 1952 to the Chief Conservator of Forests, Himachal Pradesh, requring that Officer to submit the matters in difference to the arbitration of the Deputy Commissioner, Mandi District.

facts.text: Chief Conservator replied on June 23, 1952 declining reference, contending matters outside arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: By his reply dated June 23, 1952, the Chief Conservator declined to agree to a reference companytending that the matters desired to be referred to were outside the arbitration clause.

facts.text: On June 22, 1955 appellants applied to District Court of Chamba for filing agreement dated November 1, 1950 and referring disputes to arbitration of Deputy Commissioner, Mandi.

anchor.surface_text: On June 22, 1955 the appellants applied to the District Court of Chamba for an order that the agreement dated November 1, 1950 be filed in the Court and that the disputes between them and the State be referred to the sole arbitration of the Deputy Commissioner, Mandi District.

facts.text: State of Himachal Pradesh contended application barred by limitation, right to apply arose in 1950 or on June 23, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Himachal Pradesh, companytended, inter alia, that the application for filing the arbitration agreement was barred by the law of limitation as the right to apply, if any, arose in the year 1950 and number on June 23, 1952, as alleged.

facts.text: Court of First Instance (District Court Chamba) held Limitation Act does not govern application under s.20 Arbitration Act, or if does, within 3 years from June 23, 1952 refusal, not barred; ordered filing and reference.

anchor.surface_text: The Court of First Instance held that the Limitation Act did number govern an application for filing an arbitration agreement under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, and that even if the application was governed by Art. 181 of Sch. 1 of the Limitation Act, 1908, since the application was made within three years from the date on which the Chief Conservator of Forests, Himachal Pradesh, declined to make a reference, it was number barred. The Court accordingly ordered that the agreement be filed and the disputes be referred to the arbitrator named in the agreement.

facts.text: During pendency of application, Part C State of Himachal Pradesh became Union Territory, Union of India substituted as party.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this application before the Trial Court, the Part C State of Himachal Pradesh became Union Territory, and the Union of India was substituted as a party in place of the State of Himachal Pradesh.

facts.text: Union of India appealed, Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh reversed trial court order.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the Union of India, the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh, reversed the order of the Trial Court.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner held application under s.20 governed by Art.181 Limitation Act, period from disputes in Sept-Oct 1950 or Sept 1, 1951, barred.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Judicial Commissioner an application for filing an arbitration agreement under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act is governed by Art. 181 of the Limitation Act, and since the period of three years prescribed thereby companymences to run from the date on which the differences arose between the parties, i.e., about the month of September-October 1950, and in any case on September 1, 1951, the application for reference filed by the appellants was barred.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Judicial Commissioner order, restored trial court order for filing agreement and referring to arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner was, in our judgment, in error in rejecting the application of the appellants for filing the arbitra- L.R. 561. 128. tion agreement as barred under Art. 181 of the Limitation Act, 1908. We direct that the appeal be allowed, the order passed by the Judicial Commissioner be set aside and the order passed by the Trial Court for filing the arbitration agreement and referring the matters to the arbitrator be restored.

The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. Under an agreement dated November 1, 1950, with the State of Himachal Pradesh, Triloknath Mahajan-second appellant in this appeal-purchased the right to extract and companylect certain medicinal herbs from the forests of Chamba District.

facts.text: Counsel: L. Gosain and Harbans Singh for appellants; D. Mahajan and R. N. Sachthey for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: L. Gosain and Harbans Singh, for the appellants. D. Mahajan and R. N. Sachthey, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

issues.text: Whether an application for filing an arbitration agreement under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 is governed by Art. 181 of the Limitation Act, 1908

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Judicial Commissioner an application for filing an arbitration agreement under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act is governed by Art. 181 of the Limitation Act, and since the period of three years prescribed thereby commences

issues.text: Whether s. 37(1) of the Arbitration Act, 1940 applies the provisions of the Limitation Act, 1908 to court applications under s. 20 for filing an arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Union of India contended that s. 37 1  of the Arbitration Act, 1940, indicates a contrary intention. That sub-section provides All the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908, shall apply to arbitrations as they apply to proceedings in Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Judicial Commissioner in error; Art.181 only for CPC applications

arguments.claim: Art. 181 only relates to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: The terms of Art. 181 are general, and are apparently number restricted to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure. But that Article is included in the group of articles which fall under the head Third Division Applications. As originally enacted all applications companytemplated to be made under Arts. 158 to 180, were applications made under the Code of Civil Procedure

arguments.claim: in Hansraj Gupta v. Official Liquidators, art. 181 only relates to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: In Hansraj Gupta and Others v. Official Liquidators of the Dehradun-Mussoorie Electric Tramway Company Ltd. 1  the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council observed at p. 20 but a series of authorities companymencing with Bai Manekbai v. Manekji Kayasji  I.L.R. 7 Bom. 213  has taken the view that art. 181 only re- lates to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure,

arguments.claim: in Sha Mulchand v. Jawahar Mills, Art. 181 has added words 'under the Code'

anchor.surface_text: In Sha Mulchand Company Ltd.  In liquidation  v. Jawahar Mills Ltd., 2  this Court observed after referring to certain decisions ,,This long catena of decisions may well be said to have, as it were, added the words under the Code in the first companyumn of that article  Art. 181 .,

arguments.claim: in Bombay Gas Company v. Gopal Bhiwa, art. 181 applies only to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: and in Bombay Gas Company Ltd. v. Gopal Bhiva Others 1  this Court observed It is well settled that art. 181 applies only to applications which are made under the Code of Civil Procedure

arguments.claim: amendment of Arts. 158 and 178 by Arbitration Act does not alter interpretation of Art. 181

anchor.surface_text: By the amendment made by the Arbitration Act 10 of 1949, Arts. L. R. 60 1. A. 13.  2  1953 S. C. R. 351.  3  1964 3 S. C. R. 709. 158 and 178 were modified and in the articles for the expression under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 the words under the Arbitration Act 1940 were substituted. The reason which persuaded the Courts ... did number companytinue to apply after the amendment

arguments.claim: s. 37(1) of the Arbitration Act indicates contrary intention that Limitation Act applies to s.20 applications

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Union of India companytended that s. 37 1  of the Arbitration Act, 1940, indicates a companytrary intention. That sub-section provides All the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908, shall apply to arbitrations as they apply to proceedings in Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Code of Civil Procedure and the Indian Arbitration Act, 1899, were repealed and an Act dealing with all arbitrations was enacted, and it was found nec

arguments.court_reasoning: s.37 applies Limitation Act to arbitrations (arbitrator proceedings), not to court applications under s.20

arguments.claim: s. 37(1) applies provisions of Limitation Act to arbitrations (proceedings before arbitrator), not to court applications under s.20

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this clause does number govern an application for filing an arbitration agreement under, s. 20 of the Arbitration Act. In terms, it provides, that the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act apply to arbitrations as they apply to proceedings in Court. In other words, an arbitrator in dealing with a matter submitted to him is bound to apply the provisions of the Limitation Act

arguments.claim: genesis of s.37(1) in Ramdutt Ramkissen-dass v. F.D. Sasson; it codifies that arbitrator must apply Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: The genesis of this sub-section is to be found in the judgment of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Ramdutt Ramkissen- dass v. F. D. Sasson and Company 1 . In that case the Judicial Committee observed that even though s. 3 of the Limitation Act deals primarily with suits, appeals and applications made in law companyrts ... the arbitrator must decide ... according to the existing law

arguments.claim: under s.20, court checks existence of valid subsisting agreement and arisen dispute within jurisdiction, but not whether claim barred by limitation; that is for arbitrator

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with an application for filing an arbitration agreement, the Court must satisfy itself about the existence of a written agreement which is valid and sub- sisting and which has been executed before the institution of any suit, and also that a dispute has arisen with regard to the subjectmatter of the agreement which is within the jurisdiction of the Court. But the Court is number companycerned ... barred by the law of limitation that question falls within the province of the arbitrator

holdings.text: An application for filing an arbitration agreement under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 is not governed by Art. 181 of the Limitation Act, 1908 as Art. 181 only governs applications under the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: If Art. 181 of the Limitation Act only governs applications under the Code of Civil Procedure for which no period of limitation is provided under the Schedule, an application under the Arbitration Act, 1940 not being an application under the Code of Civil Procedure, unless there is some provision, which by express enactment or plain intendment to the contrary in the Arbitration Act, will not be governed by that Article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 181 in Third Division for CPC applications; consistent precedents restrict to CPC despite generality; amendments to Arts. 158/178 do not alter; applied analogously from Companies Act and other cases.

holdings.text: Section 37(1) of the Arbitration Act, 1940 applies Limitation Act provisions to arbitrations (proceedings before the arbitrator) and does not govern court applications under s. 20 for filing arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this clause does not govern an application for filing an arbitration agreement under, s. 20 of the Arbitration Act. In terms, it provides, that the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act apply to arbitrations as they apply to proceedings in Court. In other words, an arbitrator in dealing with a matter submitted to him is bound to apply the provisions of the Limitation Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading limits to 'arbitrations'; genesis in Privy Council case codifying arbitrator's duty to apply limitation, not court applications to enforce reference.

holdings.text: In dealing with an application under s. 20, the court is not concerned with whether the claim is barred by limitation; that question is for the arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: But the Court is not concerned in dealing with that application to deal with the question whether the claim of a party to the arbitration agreement is barred by the law of limitation that question falls within the province of the arbitrator

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court's role under s.20 limited to valid subsisting agreement, arisen dispute, jurisdiction; limitation defence belongs to arbitrator as in court proceedings.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; order of Judicial Commissioner set aside; Trial Court order filing agreement and referring disputes to arbitrator restored.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner was, in our judgment, in error in rejecting the application of the appellants for filing the arbitra- L.R. 561. 128. tion agreement as barred under Art. 181 of the Limitation Act, 1908. We direct that the appeal be allowed, the order passed by the Judicial Commissioner be set aside and the order passed by the Trial Court for filing the arbitration agreement and referring the matters to the arbitrator be restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial Commissioner erred on application of Art.181; lower courts partially correct; restore to proceed to arbitration.

Manekji Kayasji I.L.R. 7 Bom. 213 has taken the view that art. 181 only re- lates to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure, in which case no period of limitation has been prescribed for the application.

precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 181 of the Limitation Act only relates to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: Bai Manekbai v. Manekji Kayasji I.L.R. 7 Bom. 213 has taken the view that art. 181 only re- lates to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure, in which case no period of limitation has been prescribed for the application. In Sha Mulchand Company Ltd. In liquidation v. Jawahar Mills Ltd., 2 this Court observed after referring to certain decisions ,,This long catena of decisions may well be said to have, as it were, added the words under the Code in the first column of that article Art. 181 ., and in Bombay Gas Company Ltd. v. Gopal Bhiva Others 1 this Court observed It is well settled that art. 181 applies only to applications which are made under the Code of Civil Procedure

precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 181 of the Limitation Act only relates to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure

precedents.citation: Sha Mulchand Company Ltd. In liquidation v. Jawahar Mills Ltd., 2

anchor.surface_text: Sha Mulchand Company Ltd. In liquidation v. Jawahar Mills Ltd., 2 this Court observed after referring to certain decisions ,,This long catena of decisions may well be said to have, as it were, added the words under the Code in the first column of that article Art. 181 ., and in Bombay Gas Company Ltd. v. Gopal Bhiva Others 1 this Court observed It is well settled that art. 181 applies only to applications which are made under the Code of Civil Procedure It is true that in Hansraj Guptas case, 1 the Judicial Committee was dealing with the period of limitation for filing an application under s. 186 1 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913, to order a contributory in a winding-up to pay a debt and Sha Mulchands case 2 related to an application under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, for rectification of the share-register and restoration of the name of a member whose shares were forfeited for non-payment of calls.

precedents.case_name: Sha Mulchand Company Ltd. (In Liquidation) v. Jawahar Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 181 of the Limitation Act only relates to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure; long catena added 'under the Code' to Art. 181
precedents.cited_holding: This long catena of decisions may well be said to have, as it were, added the words under the Code in the first column of that article Art. 181

precedents.citation: Bombay Gas Company Ltd. v. Gopal Bhiva Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Bombay Gas Company Ltd. v. Gopal Bhiva Others 1 this Court observed It is well settled that art. 181 applies only to applications which are made under the Code of Civil Procedure It is true that in Hansraj Guptas case, 1 the Judicial Committee was dealing with the period of limitation for filing an application under s. 186 1 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913, to order a contributory in a winding-up to pay a debt and Sha Mulchands case 2 related to an application under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, for rectification of the share-register and restoration of the name of a member whose shares were forfeited for non-payment of calls. In the Bombay Gas Companys case 1 this Court was dealing with an application for enforcement of an order under s. 33C 2 of the Industrial Disputes Act 14 of 1947 for computation of benefit in terms. of money and for a direction to the employers to pay the same.

precedents.case_name: Bombay Gas Company Ltd. v. Gopal Bhiva Others
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 181 of the Limitation Act applies only to applications which are made under the Code of Civil Procedure
precedents.cited_holding: It is well settled that art. 181 applies only to applications which are made under the Code of Civil Procedure

precedents.citation: Ramdutt Ramkissen- dass v. F. D. Sasson and Company 1

anchor.surface_text: Ramdutt Ramkissen- dass v. F. D. Sasson and Company 1 . In that case the Judicial Committee observed that even though s. 3 of the Limitation Act deals primarily with suits, appeals and applications made in law courts and makes no reference to arbitration proceedings and, therefore, the Limitation Act does not in terms apply to arbitrations in mercantile references, it would be an implied term of the contract that the arbitrator must decide the dispute according to the existing law of contract, and that every defence which would have been open in a Court of law can be equally proposed for the arbitrators decision unless the parties have agreed to exclude that defence.

precedents.case_name: Ramdutt Ramkissendas v. F. D. Sasson and Company
precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of Limitation Act apply to arbitrations as an implied term of the contract, requiring arbitrator to apply limitation law as in court
precedents.cited_holding: it would be an implied term of the contract that the arbitrator must decide the dispute according to the existing law of contract, and that every defence which would have been open in a Court of law can be equally proposed for the arbitrators decision unless the parties have agreed to exclude that defence

anchor.surface_text: If Art. 181 of the Limitation Act only governs applications under the Code of Civil Procedure for which no period of limitation is provided under the Schedule, an application under the Arbitration Act, 1940 not being an application under the Code of Civil Procedure, unless there is some provision, which by express enactment or plain intendment to the contrary in the Arbitration Act, will not be governed by that Article.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this clause does not govern an application for filing an arbitration agreement under, s. 20 of the Arbitration Act. In terms, it provides, that the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act apply to arbitrations as they apply to proceedings in Court. In other words, an arbitrator in dealing with a matter submitted to him is bound to apply the provisions of the Limitation Act
